loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en: Altangerel T. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Uvurhangai province, central Mongolia. Her oldest daughter is a university student while her youngest daughter works as a private businesswoman. Since 1999, she has been operating a milk, dairy products and grocery trading business in a rented stall at the local market. During the summertime she sells mare's milk (fermented milk) and has become quite experienced in the trade over the many years. She hopes to continue operating her business with stability.  In the future, she dreams of establishing her own dairy product processing factory. Altangerel is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase dairy products and other goods at wholesale prices for her trading business.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products and other goods at wholesale prices

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase grocery products

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites E. is a married woman who lives in Purok 1, Brgy. Culipapa, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  fishing and fish vending businesses. Her husband Vito E., who is 40 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who are between 4 and 21 years old.

Marites joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marites has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy fishing gear and equipment for her fishing boat, so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Marites E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Sophak

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophak M. (shown in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Saroeun Um, have been married since 1984 and have three children: one son and two daughters. The son is a construction worker, one daughter is in university and another one attends grade 12. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sophak has been selling cooked porridge and Khmer noodles, or Num Banh Chok in her village since 2000. Khmer noodles are considered the national dish of Cambodia and can be served with a green curry soup and banana flowers, bean sprouts, water lily stalks and cucumber. Her husband is a motorcycle repairman.

Sophak is asking for her first loan of $700 to pay school fees for her daughter who is in university. She will use a part of her loan to repair the kitchen where she cooks.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her daughters and to repair the kitchen where she cooks.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena N. is from the village of Olango. She is 51 years old. Nena is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Nena owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Nena has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 45,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2008, Nena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Nena is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Nena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou T. is from the city of Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 41 years old. Marilou is widowed and has two school-age children. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling variety of different products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng S. has been spending his life cultivating crops. This is a skill he had learned from his grandparents when he was young. Chheng S. is now married and has four children who are all single. His wife frequently works with him in the farm fields. Growing crops is an annual activity with which he has had great success. Chheng S. is able to plant crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. 

Besides of farming business, Chheng S. is earning extra income by climbing the palm trees behind his house to extract palm juice. Palm tree-climbing jobs are very common for poor people who live in the commune. The containers which he always uses for storing palm juice have broken down or are getting old. He would like to purchase some new containers for storing palm juice use the rest of the loan for supplies for his farming business.

Chheng S. and his wife are pictured in this photo.

loans.use: To purchase some containers for storing palm juice and to purchase supplies for his farming business.

loans.name: Naiteang

texts.en:
Mrs. Naiteang Y. (shown in the photo) is 42 years old and her husband, Mr. Met Mer, is 42 years old. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They have one daughter who attending grade 12. 

Naiteang has been growing and selling flowers and bananas for 15 years. She buys some flowers and bananas from the fellow villagers for resale in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a soldier. 

Naiteang wants to supplement a new business of raising pigs, so she is applying for her first loan of $1,000 to launch the business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa R. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Pag-asa, Barangay Port Barton, San Vicente, Palawan. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a farming business. Her husband, Leartes R., is 62 years old. He works as a street worker to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 5 children who are between 13 and 30 years old. 

Leonisa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Leonisa has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 4th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use towards the purchase of more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. 

Leonisa R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Bunthoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Bunthoeun N. (shown in the photo), is 46 years old and his wife, Mrs. Phalla Sou, is 38 years old. They have been married since 1991 and have three children: one son and two daughters. All three children are in school. The family lives in a small village along National Road number five, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Bunthoeun has been driving a Tuk Tuk taxi for two years. His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Battulga B. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and two children in their own house with fence in the Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. The family has been living in their current home for the past nine years. 

Her husband works in the 256th squad as a soldier and her two children both attend a local school. Since 2004, she has been operating a business trading dairy products, milk and groceries in a rented stall at the local market. During the summertime, she sells mare's milk (fermented milk) and has been quite experienced in the trade over the many years. 

She hopes to continue to operate her business as a stable operation and in the future, she dreams to establish her own dairy-product processing factory. 

Battulga is requesting a 1,500,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase dairy products and other goods at wholesale prices for her trading business. Also, she wants to grow her milk-products business.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products

loans.name: Leticia

She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. Nemesia C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Bernadette's Group

texts.en:
Bernadette B. is from the village of Pulay, Luna Isabela. She is 42 years old. Bernadette is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Bernadette is married and has two school age children. To make a living, Bernadette owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Bernadette has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Bernadette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernadette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Bernadette is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Bernadette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou T., 57, is married and lives with three of her children in the Takeo province. Working a farm together with her husband, Sou T. typically makes US$3 each day. Her family is also supported by two of her children who work in the garment factory and one child who is in construction. Sou T. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Bumtsend

texts.en: Bumtsend B. is 60 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent and fence. His two daughters are attending secondary school. Bumtsend operates a firewood and coal selling business with the help of his wife in the Tsaiz market, the biggest raw materials market in the city. He has been engaged in this business for the past three  years and has gained much experience. He purchases one truckload of coal at 280,000 MNT and packages them into 450-500 bags to sell at 850 MNT per bag. He sells firewood in addition to coal. He usually operates his coal and firewood trading business during the winter months and manages a mare's milk trading business in the summer months. Bumtsend is a hardworking and honest man. For the future, he says, "I would like to buy a truck for my business." Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. texts.en:
Nazarboy I. is 43 years old. He is married with 3 children. Nazarboy has dedicated himself to the cattle breeding business for the past 10 years. He purchases calves to raise, fatten, and then sells them or butchers them to sell the meat. His children help Nazarboy with his business. Today, his major need is acquiring cattle for his business. For this reason, Nazarboy looks for support from IMON International, to buy more cattle and fodder. This will make his family’s sustenance possible.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

texts.en: Tolibjon is a married father of 4 children. His family lives in Istaravshan where Tolibjon runs a wholesale business selling juice and soft drinks. Tolibjon's store is well known in this neighborhood as he serves his customers well and works late hours. Tolibjon has been in this business for 25 years. Now he is seeking a loan of 7000 somoni to purchase more juice and soft drinks to increase the stock he offers. Moreover, Tolibjon is hoping to spend a portion of the loan to buy insulation materials for his store to prepare it for the upcoming cold season. Tolibjon has had some struggles as his business was growing and becoming self-sustainable. However, he handled all these challenges well and is looking toward to the future with much enthusiasm and optimism. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country, known for its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a wider range of juice and soft drinks

loans.name: Carlina's Group

texts.en:
Carlina G. is from the village of Manaoag, Cauayan City, Isabela.  Carlina, who is 60 years old, is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Carlina is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Carlina sells animal feed to local farmers. Carlina has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Carlina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Carlina is requesting a new loan, her fifth from ASKI, for 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Ganchimeg

texts.en: Ganchimeg C. is a 42 year-old widow who lives with her four children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her children live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest son attends university while her youngest two children, 9 and 7 years old, both attend a local primary school. Ganchimeg operates a fruit and vegetable retail business in the Bars market, one of the largest wholesale fruit and vegetable trading markets in the city. She began her business in 1990 selling vegetables in the Harhorin market of the city. Her earnings have enabled her to start building a house in her yard. In the future, she plans to continue growing her business and establish her own grocery shop with help of her son. Ganchimeg is a hardworking and honest woman and is requesting a 750,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials to build her house and to buy more sewing materials for herself.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to build her house

loans.name: Chheav

texts.en: Chheav L. is 50-year-old single mother. She lives with her six children, five of whom are single and one is married. Two of her children are working in a garment factory and share responsibility with her to support the family’s expenses. Chheav L. owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows a rice crop and potatoes on her farmland, which she will sell to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. It is the  planting season now, however Chheav L. doesn’t have capital to use to plant crops.. Chheav L. is asking for a loan to use towards purchasing fertilizers, and seeds for planting.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Gonchigsuren

texts.en:
Gonchigsuren C. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Selenge province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent and fence. Her older children all are grown up and live on their own and her youngest daughter, age 7, attends a local primary school. Her husband is retired and currently works as a guard in the Golomt Bank after working in the police department. 

Gonchigsuren operates a second hand consumer goods trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town. She has been engaged in this business since 2008 and has gained significant experience. She sells a variety of consumer goods that can satisfy her customers's needs. Her earnings have enabled him to buy car for her husband. 

Gonchigsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to imports new clothing items from Erlian, a border city of China, in order to increase her product line for her used consumer goods trading business.

loans.use: To import new clothing items for resale

loans.name: Antonia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Antonia de 46 años, tiene una tienda de confites y snack. Vive en una zona periurbana en la perimetral de Guayaquil rodeada de un estero.

Empezó hace 6 años atrás vendiendo confites en su casa para mantener a sus tres hijos ya que no está casada. Tiene su tienda en la casa y trabaja desde las 06h00am hasta 23h00pm.  Como sus hijos ya son mayores de edad ahora ella se dedica solo a trabajar para sus nietos. Vende dulces, galletas, bebidas, arroz, confites. Con el préstamo ella quiere comprar confites e implementar tarjetas para teléfonos celulares. 

En el futuro quiere agrandar mas su negocio y hacerlo más visible para los vecinos nuevos del sector.
texts.en:
Antonia is 46 years old. She has a store where she sells candy and savoury snacks. She lives on the outskirts of the city of Guayaquil, on the edge of the estuary.

Six years ago, she started selling sweets from home in order to support her three children, because she is not married. She has her store in her house and works from 6 am until 11pm. Because her children are grown up now, she dedicates herself to her work for the benefit of her grandchildren. She sells sweets, cookies, drinks, rice and candies. With the loan she wants to buy candy and start selling cellphone calling cards.

In the future she wants to expand her business more and make it more visible to neighbours moving into the area.

loans.use: Candy, cellphone top-up cards

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for building.

loans.name: Gladys Piedad

texts.es:
Gladys de 60 años, tiene una tienda de víveres de productos de primera necesidad. Vive en una zona periurbana en la perimetral de Guayaquil rodeada de un estero.

Cuando cumplió 50 años decidió tener su tienda en su casa para asegurar la vejez ya que es separada de su esposo. Tiene su tienda en la casa y trabaja desde las 08h00am hasta 21h00pm. Vende arroz, azúcar, bebidas, enlatados en su tienda de víveres. Con el préstamo ella quiere comprar arroz, azúcar, bebidas. 

En el futuro quiere agrandar mas su negocio y construir mejor su casa para asegurar su vejez y ayudarle a sus hijos con sus gastos.
texts.en:
Gladys, 60, has a grocery and basic need items store.  She lives in a periurban area along Guayaquil’s beltway that’s surrounded by a marsh.

When she turned 50 she decided to set up a store in her home to insure her old age because she’s separated from her husband.  She has her store in her house and she works from 8am until 9pm.  She sells rice, sugar, beverages and canned goods in her foodstuffs store.  She will use the loan to buy rice, sugar and beverages.

In the future she’d like to enlarge the store and build her house better to insure her old age and help her children with their expenses.

loans.use: For rice and sugar.

loans.name: Naisimoi Ene

texts.en:
Naisimoi has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last 4 years. She is 22 years old, married to N. Nkuya, and they have two children.

She was introduce to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan amount to buy 10 goats, which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

In the future, Naisimoi hopes to grow her business so that she will be able to comfortably take her children to school.

loans.use: To buy 10 goats which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Jenishbubu

texts.en:
Jenishbubu S. is 42-year-old widow with two children. She graduated from medical college and worked as a nurse at the local hospital. She was characterized by her colleagues as a very precise and good-natured person.

In 1993, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Jenishbubu decided to engage in cattle breeding and land cultivating. Her hardworking efforts allowed her to develop her farm to two cows, one horse, ten sheep and to earn her living through selling milk and harvesting.    

Jenishbubu plans to use the loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden her business by purchasing two milk cows and manure to fertilize her land. With the revenues from this investment, Jenishbubu plans to buy a truck for transporting meat and milk products. 
  
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and fertilizers.

loans.name: Corazon's Group

texts.en:
Corazon A. is from the village of Christine Village,District 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 51 years old. Corazon is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Corazon is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling personal use products such as lotions, talc powder, and perfumes in the local community. Corazon is just starting this business.

In 2007, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Kirera Twebeiseho Group

texts.en: K. Lydia belongs to Kirera twebeiseho group in Bushenyi. She is 40 years old and married. She has 3 children, all in school. K. Lydia is a farmer dealing in beans and maize from her home and she has been in this business for 5 years. She deals in the sale of coffee from her home as well. She is a very hard working lady and she needs a loan to be able to buy beans and coffee for resale.

loans.use: Buying beans and coffee for resale.

loans.name: Tenke Ole Napuku

texts.en:
Tenke Ole Napuku, aged 40 years, is married to Saruni, a farmer and together they have five children: leparakuo, aged 22 years, Olobulu aged 20 years, Naeku, aged 17 years, Ntanani, aged 15 years and Nkaleyia, aged 12 years. They live in Bissil village and trade livestock at Bissil market in Kajiado, which is a busy market. Tenke sells his livestock to butcher men in Kitengela and Kajiado for slaughter. 

Tenke was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients. He has been running his livestock trading business for a period of two years and he gets a monthly profit of KES 26,000.

With the KES 40,000 loan, which is his first loan with KADET, he plans to use KES 20,000 to buy cows, KES 10,000 to buy goats and KES 10,000 to buy sheep, all for trading. If the loan boosts the business he will buy a pickup for transportation purposes.

Tenke's dream is to open a butchery in Kajiado. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy cows, goats and sheep for trade.

loans.name: Manuel's Group

texts.en:
Manuel N. is from the village of Lalog 2 Luna, Isabela. He is 44 years old. Manuel is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Manuel is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Manuel owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Manuel has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP every four months.

In 2010, Manuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manuel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Manuel is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Manuel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Beth Njeri

texts.en:
Beth Njeri, aged 29 years, is a single mother of one child, Cynthia Mumbi, aged six, in pre unit. She lives in Kitengela and has her general shop there. She sells cooking fat, sugar, flour, fruit and vegetables among other items. She was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

Beth has been running this business for six years and her monthly profit is Kshs 10,000. This loan of Kshs 90,000 is her fourth loan with KADET and she plans to use Kshs 40,000 to buy fruits and vegetable, and Kshs 50,000 to buy sugar, flour and other items. If this loan boosts the business, she will use the anticipated profit to  pay school fees for her daughter.

Beth describes herself as hardworking and dreams of becoming a prominent business lady and grow with KADET.

loans.use: To increase her stock of sugar, flour, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: K. Moses is an individual client from Kyenjojo. He has a butcher shop on Ntoroko Road where he sells goat meat, beef, and hides to the local residents. His cousin is an employee who helps with the business. Moses is able to make 600,000/= a month profit and he also grows and sells tea. Moses has been in the business for eight years and needs a loan to buy goats and cows to butcher. Moses is a hard-working man, 34 years old, and married with three children.

loans.use: Buy goats and cows for his butcher shop.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida V. is from the village of Salucong. She is 53 years old. Adelaida is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Adelaida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling health & medicinal products in the local community. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Adelaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelaida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Adelaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dominic Mavindu

texts.en:
Dominic Mavindu, aged 37 years, is married to Josephine Mueni, aged 30 years, and together they have two children — Mutheu, age ten, in class five and Muema, age six, in class two. He lives and has his butcher business in Mlolongo. He was introduced to KADET by other KADET clients.

Dominic has been in this business for six years and his monthly profit is Kshs 18,000. This loan of Kshs 50,000 is his second loan with KADET. The previous loan was paid back successfully. With this loan, Dominic plans to use Kshs 20,000 to buy an oven to roast meat, and Kshs 30,000 to increase the stock of meat in his butchery. If the loan boosts business he will buy a piece of land and build his own house.

Dominic describes himself as outgoing and dreams of becoming a prominent business man in the future.

loans.use: To buy an oven to roast meat and buy more meat to butcher

loans.name: Milton

texts.en: R. Milton is 30 years old and married with three children. He has a retail shop in Mubiiwa trading centre where he sells salt, soap, sugar, sodas, biscuits, and mineral water. Most of Milton’s customers shop daily and he is able to make 30,000/=  a profit weekly. Milton also owns a boda boda that he sometimes hires out if he is busy with the shop. He needs a loan to be able to stock the retail shop with more goods. Milton says that his business is the result of his own initiative and he is determined to work very hard and transform it into a wholesale business. His dream is to have a stable business and family.

loans.use: Restocking the shop with food supplies

loans.name: Fred Otieno

texts.en:
Fred Otieno is an entrepreneur in Migori, in the western part of Kenya. He is married to Jael Akinyi who sells second-hand clothing in the same town. They have three children who depend on them. 

Fred operates a clothing business where he sells new clothes both male and female. He has had this business for the last six years with great success and makes a monthly income of Kshs 25,000 — a good income in this town where the living standards are not so high. He is taking a first loan of Kshs 20,000 to buy new clothing for sale in this festive season when demand is high. He will use the profits to add more clothing to meet customer demand.

Fred hopes to expand and become a leading clothing wholesale who small-scale traders can buy from.

loans.use: To buy new stock of clothing to sell.

loans.name: Kyabyakwaga Tukole Group

texts.en: Edisa T. is the leader of Kyabyakwaga Tukole group in Kyenjojo. She is 42 years old, married, and has five children. Edisa has a retail shop in Kyabyakwaga Trading Center.  Her business has existed for over five years. Edisa has always used loans from Pearl Microfinance and they have benefited her a lot both in business and for her family. She needs a loan to help her with restocking her retail shop with more goods for resale. It is a business she started on her own and she hopes to see it expand.

loans.use: To restock her retail shop with general merchandise

loans.name: Stephen  Makanyanga

texts.en: Stephen Makanyanga M. is 28 years old and married to Judy M.. He is a sign painter who works together with his wife in this business of painting in Kitale town.  Has been in this business for four years and he earns a monthly income of thirty thousand shillings.This will be Stephen's first loan from KADET.  He plans to buy paint worth fifteen thousand shillings, also to buy paint brushes and other materials worth five thousand shillings. With the income he is going to get he plans to expand his business by employing more people to help him. Stephen hopes that with the profits he will earn that he can raise his family's living standards.

loans.use: To purchase paint, painting brushes etc

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta C. is from Capatan, Tuguegarao City. She is 42 years old. Vicenta is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Vicenta owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Vicenta has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Vicenta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vicenta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Vicenta is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Vicenta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Everline Ayuma

texts.en:
Everline Ayuma is a Kenyan entrepreneur from the county of Vihiga , an upcoming agricultural town in Western Kenya. She is married to Boaz who works with the government and they have four children  between 19 years and 7 years of age. 

Everline operates a retail shop at Chavavo location which is a suburb within the larger Vihiga town. She has successfully run this business for the last six years and she makes a monthly income of Kshs 20,000. She is taking her fourth loan from KADET Limited which she intends to use to buy more stock like rice and,sugar for her shop.She hopes to make more sales as we approach the festive season. She will use her profits to add more stock, repay her Kadet loan and pay school fees for her children.

Everline's hope is to become a wholesale business where she will be supplying to retailers within Chavavo. She also plans to buy a piece of land and build a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her retail shop

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en: Wilson M. is 35 years old and married with 4 children ages 12 – 1 year. He is in the produce buying and selling business mainly dealing in maize, ground nuts and beans from Rukizi. In his business, He and  his wife  also have a waragi (local gin) selling business. Most of Wilson’s customers are grocery store owners. Wilson  needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale to his customers. Wilson has had the business for 10 years and he used the profit from his previous textile business to buy the first stock of produce for sale. So far he has paid school fees for his children, expanded his business and also bought a piece of land.

loans.use: Buying more produce for resale.

loans.name: Erdenee

texts.en:
Erdenee O. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His three children all attend a local secondary school, while his wife works as a salesperson in the shop. Erdenee owns and operates his own wooden product business out of his own work place next to his home. He started his business in 2001 making a variety of wooden items in his home, after working and living in the countryside as a herder. Since 2008, he was able to build an extra ger where he operates his business from, next to his home. All of his products are made with great care and attention to detail which has earned him a reputation among his customers as a quality furniture provider. Erdenee is a man with principle who works very hard. 

He is requesting a 2,100,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood, a lathe, and a paint sprayer for his furniture making business.

loans.use: To purchase more wood, a lathe and a paint sprayer

loans.name: Kyenjojo Bakyara Twekambe Group

texts.en: K. Laila is the leader of her lending group of Kyenjojo Bakyara Twekambe group. She is married with 6 children aged between 18 – 3 years. Laila has had a spare parts business in Kyenjojo Trading Centre for 20 years selling motor vehicle and cycle spare parts. Her customers are mostly taxi drivers and motorists. She also has a clothing sales business that also brings in an income. Laila needs a loan to be able to buy more stock of spare parts. She is a very hard working lady and her dream is to see her children attain the best  education at University.

loans.use: Buying more stock of spare parts for resale.

loans.name: Genel

texts.en:
Mrs. Genel P. is from the Barangay of Sangay Diot, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old, married to Dexter P. and blessed with 1 child of infant age. To make a living, she is presently engaged in load retailing particularly on SMART & GLOBE. Her husband is also earns income from his driving activity. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for 1 year already. She earn's an average amount of not less than P1,000.00 a month from this kind of business. 

Just this year, Genel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genel as an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reached out to rural communities, has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php5,000.00. She is now requesting a loan of Php7,000.00 as her 1st loan which will be used for the financing of her hog raising activity and additional capital for her load retailing business. The future income of this business will be used to meet their basic needs, child’s education and loan repayments. She also joined PAGLAUM MPC because of the savings and insurance program offered by PAGLAUM MPC to its members. 

 About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Financing for her hog raising and additional capital for her cell phone card load retailing business

location.town: Sangay Diot, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mind

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en: San K. is 50 years old and lives with her parents.  She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land where she cultivates rice and different vegetables for a living. However,she does not have some needed farming supplies. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline. There are twenty one members in this village loan group. They are located in Trabaek Pok village in Kandal province. This village loan group selected San K. as the village bank president. Each member of this village will use their portion of the loan to support different purposes.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and gasoline

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna I. is a widow who lives in Sitio Cansusi, Brgy.Tapon, Dalaguete, Cebu. She earns her living by raising hogs. She has eight children who are between the ages of 9 to 29 years old.  Myrna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Myrna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 12,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 8,400 PHP, raising her family's standard of living.  For her fifth loan, she is borrowing  15,000 PHP, which she intends to use for capital in her business so that she can continue to save up for the future and for the education of her children. Myrna is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To acquire capital for hog business

loans.name: Adrien

texts.en:
Adrien is 26 years old and is single. He owns a boutique in the Gasabo district in Rwanda.  Adrien has two years experience owning his small business and works from 6am until 9pm every day. His store is very well-organised

This is Adrien's first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company.  He has requested a loan to purchase more products for his small boutique, he would like to expand his business and use the profits to open other small boutiques.

loans.use: To purchase more products for his small boutique

loans.name: Eutiquia

texts.en:
Eutiquia H. is married and has five children who are between 25 to 32 years old. She lives in Guiwang Barangay in the municipality of Alcoy on Cebu island in the western Visayas islands. Her husband, Modesto H., 65 years old, is a farmer and also helps his wife in her businesses. She has three businesses: a farm, a sari-sari store and a habal-habal (motorcycle) transport business.

Eutiquia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of 1200 PHP, lifting the family's standard of living.

For her sixth loan, she is borrowing 11,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell in her shop so that she can continue to save up to improve her house and for the education of her children. Eutiquia H. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: C6207 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Janviere is 26 years old and is married with two children who are 6 months and 3 years old.  She is the president of a group called “Abishyizehamwe” and this group is commonly known for selling a variety of goods in their various businesses, such as clothes, foodstuffs, gasoline, etc. 

Janviere and her team are now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to satisfy the demand of their customers which keeps increasing beyond their financial capacity.  With the use of this loan, Janviere and her team expect to earn more profits which, in turn, will be used to reinvest in their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: C7577  Abumvikanye Group

texts.en:
Augustin is 43 and is married with five children between the ages 3 and 10.  He is the president of a group which is called Abumvikanye.

Augustin grows rice and has been doing this for 5 years.  Augustin and his group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses and to buy organic fertilizer.  Augustin would like to buy a house with any profit he makes.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Siem Thavery's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Siem T. is nineteen years old, married and has a child who is just a year old. Her husband, Mr. Nhien Long, 26 years old, is an agri-machine driver. They live in K'am Samnar Leu village, Kandal province.

Eight people have formed a village bank and selected Siem T. as the village bank loan president. The members of this village will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes.

Siem is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare rice field. Her husband also works on the farm. Siem, however, does not have enough money to grow her rice. So she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Bienvinida

texts.en:
Mrs. Bienvinida G. is from the Barangay of Tabid, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old, married to Rodrigo G. and blessed with 4 children of whom 3 of them are now at their adult age and the other 1 is still  school aged. To make a living, she is presently engaged in direct selling business particularly AVON Products and RTW dealing. Her husband is engaged in agricultural activity. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for 10 years. She’s earning an average amount of not less than P10,000.00 a month from this kind of business. 

In May 19,2008, Bienvinida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bienvinida as an active member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP, a microfinance program that reached out to rural communities, has successfully repaid a loan amount of Php14,000.00. She is now requesting a loan of Php13,000.00 as her 5th loan which will be used for  additional capital for her direct selling of AVON Products and RTW dealing business. The future income of this business will be used to meet their basic needs, loan repayments and child’s education. She also joined PAGLAUM MPC because of the savings and insurance program offered by PAGLAUM MPC to its members. 

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her direct selling AVON Products and RTW dealing business

loans.name: Kyehemba Turihamwe Group

texts.en:
Christopher N. is the leader of the Kyehemba Turihamwe group in Kyenjojo. He is 48 years old and married with seven children aged five to nineteen years old. Christopher has been selling produce in Kyakaitaba trading center for four years. He mainly sells maize, beans, peas and so on, and in addition to this he is also involved in rearing and selling goats.

Christopher needs a loan to buy produce like dry beans and Irish potatoes for resale with the hope that he will see greater profits. Christopher is hardworking, and his dream is to have a continually stable business to support his family.

loans.use: To buy produce like dry beans and potatoes for resale

loans.name: Yen's Group

texts.en:
These thirteen members make up a village loan located in Reang Dek village in Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Yen T., who is 47 years old, to be the village bank president. With the loans received, the members will use their money to support his or her different purpose.

Mrs. Yen T. is a farmer who owns a 3-hectare plot of land used to cultivate lotus flowers to make a living. She does not have enough money to support the lotus cultivating business. She would like to ask for a loan to buy plastic to prevent animals from getting into the lotus field. 

Mrs. Yen T. is widow and has a child who is a laborer and also helps his mother with farming.

loans.use: To buy plastic to prevent animals from getting into the lotus field.

loans.name: Tumurbagana

texts.en:
Tumurbagana L. lives with his wife and five children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family have lived in their house for past 10 years. His oldest son is a police officer in the local police department and his two middle daughters, Myagmartogtoh and Tserennadmis work as a teller in the bank and manager in the Ulaanbaatar cashmare company respectively. His younger daughter attends university and his youngest son is in kindergarten. 

Tumurbagana used to work as a driver in the transportation section between 1986 and 1993. He started his car repair center business in 2002 in his home after operating a taxi service using his own car based on his many years of experience as a driver. He provides all kind of car repair services to his customers and has established a good business in his local community. Because of his many years of experience, he is known in his town for quality repairs. For the future, he plans to continue grow his business in order to provide his family and buy fuel efficient car for himself. 

He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more car repair supplies and tools from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongoia.

loans.use: To purchase more car repair supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Orozaly

texts.en:
Orozaly U. is a 52-year-old farmer who has three children. All Orozaly’s life has been closely connected with livestock breeding; he worked as a veterinarian for a long time. After the breakdown of the Soviet Union, he established his own farm with milk cows and its daily milk yield is sold to the local dairy factory. Orozaly is also engaged in cultivating beans and perennial herbs and works hard to get a good harvest.

Orozaly plans to use this loan of 50,000 KGS to expand his farm by buying milk cows, which will allow increased milk sales. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing land for cultivating. Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase milk cows

loans.name: Keo's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of ten members who are located in Reang Dek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Keo K., 53 years old, is the village bank president selected by its members. All members of this village group will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Keo K. is a farmer who owns 2-hectares of land to cultivate a variety of vegetables for a living. Even with the farming, she still earns very little income to support her family. In order to increase her income to improve the family's living conditions, Mrs. Keo K. would like to start a new business. She decided to ask for a loan to buy Khmer cake supplies; she will use the rest of the loan to cure her child. Mrs. Keo K. is a widow with one child who is a fisherman.

loans.use: To buy Khmer cake supplies

loans.name: Uyanga

texts.en:
Uyanga E. is a 27 years old young lady and lives with her sibling in an apartment in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Uyanga operates a grocery shop in a rented space with the  help of her sibling. She began her grocery business in 2009 after working as a salesperson in the Uguuj company. She rents her shop with monthly rent fees of 500,000 MNT. Uyanga has found a success with her new business and her monthly net profit is between 400,000 and 500,000 MNT while her daily sales income has reached 300,000 MNT.  Today, her working capital exceeds 3,000,000 MNT. In addition, she also runs a karaoke service to supplement her earnings. For the future, she says, “All I want is to build a house using my business earnings and move from my current rented shop to my own shop which will bring me a lot of profits." 

She is requesting an 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more groceries to sell during upcoming New Year holiday.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Mukuza Women's Group

texts.en:
K. Joachim is the leader of the Mukuza group in Kyenjojo. He is 43 years old and married with 6 children. He and his wife have a business growing tea and they have managed their business together for 8 years. Their major customer is Mabale Growers Tea Factory in Mirambi. Joachim also deals in the selling and buying of other produce, anything that sells on the market. He is able to make 100,000 UGX in monthly profits.

Joachim needs a loan to be able to purchase fertilizers for his tea farm with the hope that it will enable him to yield more output. He previously had a retail shop that yielded capital enabling him to start this business. He has been prospering even more after having bought shamba tea.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for his plantation.

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of twelve people who live in Reang Dek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Chea S., 39 years old, was selected as the village bank president by its members. All members of this village group will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Chea S. is a grocery seller in the local village. Since her grocery business is going well, she wants to expand it and so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries. She also breeds pigs at home. Her husband, Mr. Touch Bunthorn, 41 years old, is a motorbike repairer who is able to earn a small income to support his family. With their occupations, this couple is able to earn some profit to support their four children. One of the children helps with the mother's businesses and the others attend the local school.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to expand her business

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en: Millicent O., 32 years old, is from the Obunga area and is married to George. They have three children aged 11, 7 and 2. Millicent has been operating a pharmacy business for the past five years. She is applying for her second loan to help her buy more medicine to add to her stock so as to be able to meet the demands of her clients who normally come to buy from her pharmaceutical shop after visiting the doctor. The profits made from this business will be used to pay her children's school fees. Her desire is to be able to open up a bigger pharmacy in the future.

loans.use: to buy more medicine to add to her stock

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a resident of Nyamira in Western Kenya where she does mixed farming, producing maize and beans which she sells locally. She is married with two children aged eight and five.

Teresa has requested this loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She believes the dairy cow will earn her more income and improve her family's living standards. She is focused on expanding her business to five cows in five years. Teresa says that heavy rains usually damage her beans which leads to great loss in expected income.

loans.use: purchase and insurance of a dairy cow

loans.name: Samia

texts.en: Samia is a 61 years old widowed woman, mother of two children and owner of a grocery store since 1998. Samia has the responsibility for her children since their father died. She works hard to be provide everything they need. Samia is requesting a loan for the fourth time from Al Majmoua, in order to increase her merchandise, in addition to paying the school fees of her grandson. The previous loans were only for improving the business, and she was a client in good standing and pay back history. Samia hopes to expand her business, in order to provide herself and her family with a secure living in the future.

loans.use: To increase her merchandise and pay the school fees of her grandson

loans.name: John Ntuala

texts.en:
John Ntuala, 30 years old, is married to Sayiaton, a farmer, and together they have a 4-year-old child, Naserian, in class one. They live in Enkaroni village in Kajiado. John trades livestock at the busy Bissil market in Kajiado. He sells his livestock to butchers in Kitengela and Kajiado for slaughter and to Kenya meat commission suppliers. 

John was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Kitengela office. He has been running his livestock trading business for a period of two years and he makes a monthly profit of KES 4,000.

John has applied for his first loan from  KADET, which he plans to use as follows: KES 20,000 to buy cows, KES 5,000 to buy goats and KES 5,000 to buy sheep, all for trading. If the loan boosts the business, he will buy a piece of land and build commercial houses. John’s dream is to open a butchery in Kajiado and start supplying meat to Nairobi. He describes himself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to buy cows, goats and sheep for trading

loans.name: Hamzeh

texts.en: Hamzeh is a 56 old married man and father of three children. Hamzeh has owned a coffee shop since 2000, with 20 years of experience in such a field. Hamzeh is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the first time, in order to buy a fridge, an air conditioner and the necessary materials for such a business. Hamzeh’s clients like visiting him and sitting with their old friends in his small express cafe (coffee shop), because he’s hard worker, clean and friendly. He also provides Arguileh (Hooka), and that’s what improves his business these days. His clients are of different ages. His dream was to own a big coffee shop and hopes to achieve it one day.

loans.use: To buy a fridge, an air conditioner and the necessary materials for such a business

loans.name: Richard

texts.fr:
Papa Richard comme ses amis aime bien  l’appeler, est commerçant  depuis
10ans, il vend les produits frais et congelés au marché de plateaux de 15ans ou il occupe une baraque.

Le prêt passé lui a permis d’acheter des produits tels que : saucissons ail, saucissons secs, boîtes de petits pois, macédoines, jus de fruits naturels, pots de mayonnaises, huile raffinées pour les plats froids, vinaigre….tout ces produits ont été souvent réclamé par ses clients qui venait s' approvisionner dans sa boucherie/poissonnerie.
Il a suivi et reçu les enseignements, il peut comprendre maintenant  certains thèmes comme  la gestion de stock, le journal de caisse, l’étude de faisabilité, et il a appris comment faire des épargnes. 

Ses revenus journaliers sont passés de100000f à 250000f par jour.
Avec le prochain prêt, il va acheter  plus des cartons de : cuisses de poulets, poulets à bouillir, viande arrière, viande avant, queue de bœuf, queue de porc, pieds de porc, tripes de bœuf, langues de bœuf et différentes types de poissons.
Il compte générer plus de bénéfices pour prétendre ouvrir un coin de vente dans un autre marché.
 Sa vie situation familiale a changer, cela fait 2mois qu’il ne loue plus, il habite chez lui maintenant.
Ses enfants vont à l’école dans des bonnes conditions.
texts.en:
Papa Richard, as his friends like to call him, has been a businessman for ten years. He sells fresh and frozen products at the Plateaux de 15 ans market where he has a shack. 

The previous loan he received allowed him to buy products such as: garlic sausages, summer sausages, cans of peas, mixed vegetables, natural fruit juices, pots of mayonnaise, refined oils for cold dishes, and vinegar. All these products were often requested by his customers, who came to stock up in his butcher's/fish shack. 

He has had training and now understands certain aspects of business such as stock management, keeping a cash register and feasibility studies; he has also learned how to save.

His daily turnover has gone from 100,000 francs to 200,000 francs. With the next loan he is going to buy more boxes of: chicken legs, chickens to boil, hind and front quarters of meat, oxtail, pigtails, beef tripe, beef tongue and various types of fish. 

He is expecting to make more profit in order to be able to open a sales point in another market. His living conditions have changed since he has not rented for two months and now lives in his own home. His children are at school in good conditions.

loans.use: Purchase of boxes of meat, chops, chicken breast, chicken wings etc...

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr:
Cliente de 46 ans, mariée et mère de de 5 ans enfants,a commence la vente de la friperie en 2004, très enthousiaste en 2010, elle est octroyé pour un prêt de 250000frs et elle renforce son capital et achète tous ce dont ces clients ont besoin comme les serviettes, les body, les peignoirs et draps non utilises.
Ce prêt lui a rapportée beaucoup de bénéfices et elle a épargnée comme jamais elle l'a fait et a assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
Avec le second de prêt, elle compte renforcer encore son capital et agrandir le stock de ses  marchandises tel que les serviettes, peignoirs, draps  pour satisfaire aux besoins de sa clientèle. 
en tout cas elle tient a aller au bout de ses ambitions pour être une femme d'affaire de renommée
texts.en:
This customer, who is 46 years old, married and mother to five children, began selling second-hand clothing in 2004. She is still very enthusiastic about her business in 2010 and has already been granted a loan of 250,000 francs, with which she boosted her capital and bought everything her customers needed, such as towels, bodysuits, dressing gowns and non-used sheets. This loan brought in significant profits and she has saved like never before and also covered her children's schooling costs. 

With the second loan, she is planning to boost her capital even further and expand her stock of goods, such as towels, dressing gowns and sheets, in order to satisfy customer demand. In all cases she is determined to achieve her ambition to become a reputable businesswoman.

loans.use: Purchase of bundles of towels, dressing gowns and non-used sheets

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.fr:
Client de 46 ans, célibataire avec deux enfants a charge dont l’âge varie entre 15 et 16 ans. Ayant arrête ses études au lycée par manque de moyens financiers, il se lance dans les petits métiers pour se prendre en charge.
En 1986, il ouvre un parking –lavage et gardiennage auto.
Ses services n’étant pas très fiables, tant bien que mal, il se débrouillait comme il pouvait, des qu’il a été 
finance il avait acheté d'un cracheur d'eau, des tuyaux,il avait aussi réhabilité l'abonnement de la SNE d'eau et achete des tonneaux pour conserver l'eau au moment des coupures.
Ce premier prêt a eu un impact considérable dans sa vie , il a tenu une gestion est plus saine, il a appris a contrôler le prix de revient, le bénéfice, la valeur de l’entreprise	Il a épargné comme jamais il l’a fait ;
Avec le second prêt, il va renforcer son activité en achetant un autre appareil pour laver les voitures, des différents détergents pour laver vitres, pare brises .
Tres enthousiaste ,il compte aller loin avec HOPE
texts.en:
This client is a 46 year old single man with two children, who are between the ages of 15 and 16. Due to a lack of funds, he stopped his education in high school and started taking odd jobs in order to support himself. 

In 1986, he opened a car wash and car-guarding business. Although public services were not very reliable, he managed what he could and with financing, he purchased pipes and a spigot for access to water, he also renewed his account with the national water supply services ("SNE d'eau") and purchased barrels to conserve water during cuts in water service. 

This first loan had a considerable impact on his life. His business management is much healthier: he has learned to control costs, profits and the value of his business. As always, he has been keeping savings. 

With this second loan, he would like to strengthen his business by buying another device for washing cars and different detergents for washing windows/ windshields. 

He is very enthusiastic and intends to go further with HOPE (the micro-finance institution he belongs to).

loans.use: To purchase water pipes, a spigot and soaps for washing cars

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.fr:
Elle a voulu acheter plus pour renforcer son stock de marchandise avec le prêt passé, cela à été une bonne expérience car elle a remboursée sans problèmes.

Avec le prochain prêt, elle compte renforcée son activité en achetant 
4cartons de thon, 4cartons de morue, 4cartons de soles et 2 cartons de crovines.
Ses revenus sont passés de 30000f à 50000f par jour.
Le prochain prêt va lui permettre d’appliquer ce qu’elle a appris pendant le premier cycle.
Sa vie à changée, son commerce à aussi bénéficier d’une bonne gestion, Elle est  capable de contrôler ses entrées –sorties, elle veut vendre beaucoup et générée plus de bénéfices afin de réaliser son rêve, ouvrir une baraque de vente de poisson salé en gros.
Très ambitieuse, elle soutient ses enfants dans leurs études.
texts.en:
With her last loan, she wanted to be able to purchase more in order to strengthen her stock of merchandise. It was a good experience because she repaid the loan without problem. 

With the next loan, she would like to strengthen her business by purchasing four crates of tuna, four crates of cod, four crates of sole and two crates of crovines. Her daily revenues are between 30,000 francs and 50,000 francs. The next loan would enable her to apply what she learned during her first loan cycle. Her life has changed and her business has benefited from good management. She is able to control her business' input and output. She wants to sells lots of product and to generate more income in order to realize her dream of opening a stall selling salted fish in bulk.

She is very ambitious and supports her children in their studies.

loans.use: To purchase crates of salted fish: tuna, "crovines", Nile perch (aka "capitaines") and cod

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 28-year-old single man from Tayouneh. Hasan has owned a coffee shop since 2009 and has five years of experience. This is his first time requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, and it’s because he wants to buy an espresso coffee maker that's better than the small one he has now, which he thinks is necessary for improving his business. His clients are his friends, relatives, neighbors, and passersby. Hasan seeks a secure living. He hopes one day he can expand his business and make a small happy family.

loans.use: To buy an espresso coffee maker that's better than the small one he has now, which he thinks is necessary for improving his business

loans.name: Elise Patricia Anique

texts.fr:
Vendeuse de poisson salé au marché, elle exerce ce commerce depuis 8ans et elle  nourrit toute sa famille a avec  ses revenus
Le prêt passé a été comme une école pour elle, elle a appris beaucoup et remboursée sans problèmes.
Le prochain prêt sera là pour continuer ce qu’elle avait commencé à savoir .

Tous ces enseignements lui ont été bénéfiques, elle a amélioré sa manière de vendre, son comportement envers les clients.
Avec le  nouveau prêt qui vient, elle va augmentée son activité en achetant : Des cartons de poissons salés : thons, soles, morue et capitaine.
Avant le prêt passé, ses revenus journaliers étaient de 30000f, maintenant son revenu par jour est compris entre 40.000f et 60.000f.
Son but sera atteint, lorsqu’elle va être grossiste .
Pour ses enfants, elle se bat avec les moyens financiers qu’elle aura, elle veut continuer à les soutenir dans leurs scolarités.
texts.en:
This vendor sells fish in the market. She has been in this business for almost eight years and she feeds her whole family with her earnings. Her last loan was an education for her; she learned a lot and repaid the loan without problems. She will use the next loan in order to continue what she started with her previous loan. All of these lessons have been beneficial - they have improved the way she sells and her behavior towards her clients. 

With this new loan, she will grow her business by purchasing boxes of salted fish: tuna, sole, cod and Nile perch. Before her last loan, her daily earnings were 30,000 francs; now her income is between 40,000 francs and 60,000 francs a day. Her goal is to become the wholesaler. 

For her children, she struggles with the financial resources available, but she wants to continue to support them in their schooling.

loans.use: To purchase salted fish: like sole, cod, Nile perch (aka "capitaine") and tuna

loans.name: Khandjamts

texts.en:
Khandjamts is 43 years old, married and the mother of 3 children. She and her family live in a small house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her eldest daughter, Subderdene 21, is unemployed, and looking after her child at home. Her second daughter, Oyunsubd, 19, works at a construction company and the youngest son, Bayandun, 18, stays at home.

Khandjamts operates a rented stall at the market, selling construction materials. She has been operating this business since 2000. Her husband is a plumber and also helps with his wife’s business. Over the years, Khandjamts has gained a lot of experience. She is a very helpful person with a good personality. This year she is planning to purchase a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent, for her eldest daughter. She is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to increase current assets in her business.

loans.use: to increase current assets in her business

loans.name: Ommar

texts.en: Ommar is a 46-year-old married man, the father of two children. Ommar sells clothes, shoes, and accessories.
